Message.Msg: converting email users into AXIS shopping search engine.... from services to merchandise. As Seen on YAHOO. Scott Thompson's people are still developing the e-commerce web site.

Topic.Title: Mobile AXIS search + Sticky YELP-like Yahoo + 750M shoppers

Message.Msg: Who knows shopping needs of a BUSY WOMAN with millions to spend but NO TIME to go shopping?! Marissa Working 12 hour days, yet constantly having the best MOBILE AXIS search engine to help her shop pictorially so she can HUNT DOWN and narrow down her shopping trips, or just order online. If it works for Silicon Valley and NYC busy people, why wouldn't it be perfect for the rest of the world? If that is what Marissa envisioned for Loeb, I would pay her $100M 5 years EVEN she is now 6 month pregnant- a non-issue.

Topic.Title: Marissa must have put forward a good idea during her interview

Message.Msg: interesting question. I would venture to guess that since Marissa has an operational tech background, and media says that her hiring was due to her technical expertise and connection to the valley to get more people in, therefore it is very unlikely that her pitch was M&A at all... she is essentially a glorified programmer whose salary demands for the top job were probably much lower than male candidates so yahoo board thought $70 million is cheap compared to what they would probably pay to woo a top male from silicon valley's boys club. She was by comparison, a cheap hire - still woefully expensive for the limitations of her skill set - no former experience as CEO, no experience in turnaround, no experience in M&A and clearly no experience in PR, but plenty of experience in lamaze classes. Yahoo is stuck with her now, she is out of her league when it comes to handling the problems that beset yahoo. The stock will underperform while she is at the helms. Better hope Dan Loeb nudges her in the right direction and basically help her do her job, otherwise this stock is dead.

Topic.Title: Marissa must have put forward a good idea during her interview

Message.Msg: The brilliant strategy was all about a new way to siphon off the alibaba cash straight into the pockets of the board members and executives. A truly inspirational combination of old fashioned mafia skimming and modern day financial instruments designed to pull the wool over the eyes of the typical shareholder who has no idea what really goes on behind the boardroom doors. She was able to whip the money hungry hiring team into a foaming at the mouth frenzy at the prospects of converting an ordinary corporate transaction into the big $6 billion payday for insiders. It was high fives and free stock options for all around. What a day!

Message.Title: A direct dividend to shareholders is NOT a good use of AG money but a Dutch auction with a large...
Message.Msg: share repurchase of up to 500 mil shares (say in $18 to $22 range- at avg. of $20 that would be $10 bil which is about what YHOO would have with AG money along w/ Y-Jap money) would lower shares to only 700 mil which at present earnings of $1 bil is about $1.50 a share which with a PE of just 15 is $22.50/share. But then YHOO should really command a larger PE (20?) so maybe up to $30/sh with the growing value of the 20% of AG retained. What YHOO does not need is the uncertainty that MM has brought!

Message.Title: Eric Jackson (Mr. $41/share, whom has little credibility left) puts Y-Jap value in M Fool article at only....
Message.Msg: ....$4.5 bil (in cash rich split w/ $3 bil in cash and $1.5 in assets) but doesn't Y-Jap trade at a market value of over $20 bil ??? That would put YHOO's 35% at more like $7 to $8 bil??? Why not take any reasonable assets worth $2.5 bil (even Japanese assets just as long as they are not worth much less than $2.5 bil) and then the $5 bil in cash tax free, which with the approx after tax $4 bil from AG, and the $2 bil cash on hand would give YHOO $11 bil (plus $550 mil due in Y-China royalties) to do a Dutch auction and reward shareholders wiith a good price ($20 or more) and reduce outstanding shares to 700 mil or so. Also didn't YHOO have to put up some investment for Y-Jap (and $1 bil cash and Y-China for AG) which should NOT be taxable? That is, for example, in the AG $7.1 bil- less $800 mil in pref. shares leaving $6.3 bil, then isn't only $5.3 bil (less even more for Y-China value) taxable at the 35%?? That would leave YHOO more cash than has been reported. Also does all of the cash have to be brought back from China now or can they invest some there and wait for the better tax treatment which should come in the US soon??

Message.Msg: Q4 Net Sales: $11.7 billion (increase of 4% year over year) Q4 Net Income: $1.9 billion GAAP (increase of 56% year over year); $2.5 billion non-GAAP (increase of 15% year over year) Q4 Earnings per Share: $0.36 GAAP (increase of 64% year over year); $0.47 non-GAAP (increase of 18% year over year) FY 2012 Net Sales $46.1 billion (increase of 7% year over year) FY 2012 Net Income: $8.0 billion GAAP (increase of 24% year over year); $10.0 billion non-GAAP (increase of 11% year over year) FY 2012 Earnings per Share: $1.49 GAAP (increase of 27% year over year); $1.85 non-GAAP (increase of 14% year over year)

Message.Title: A digestable rumor
Message.Msg: YHOO at current price is becoming very attractive for a takeover. Some possible buyers are hesitant to buy but at the same time don't want YHOO to be taken over by their rivals. For this reason, the rumor is they might bid for the whole company for like $17 per share which will obviously rejected by YHOO BOD but that will cause YHOO to pop up over $17 which will be good for share holders and will make YHOO takeover pricier (that was the plan of bidding at $17). This might happen in a month.

Message.Title: Dan Lobe buys Yahoo, break it apart, sold everything, and doubles his money.
Message.Msg: Isn't it obvious? Yahoo keeps all 6 billion. Dan Loeb owns a huge chunk now, why would he wants to distribute that wealth? If he does, it will run Yahoo share price up and it will make the acquisition tougher. Drive down the price, make a bid for $22/share, take Yahoo private. He then pockets 6 billion dollars, which means 30billion minus 6billion, means he only paid $17 dollars per share for the entire Yahoo. Then he breaks apart the company. 1) Remaining of the Alibaba (15 billion); 2) Yahoo Japan (7 billion); 3) Core business (sell it MSFT for 15 billion). He buys Yahoo for 17 billion dollars and doubles the money. Not sure if all the numbers are right, but you get what I am saying. ONly a Private Yahoo can be broken up and sold effectively. Dan Loeb can get this done. Meanwhile, we only get a slight premium.... oh well.
